												If you take out all of the human precision and care that goes into crafting a well-balanced tactical game and replace it all with procedurally generated hocus-pocus, you have Bionic Dues, a shining example of how NOT to do a game like this.For the sake of this review, I'm going to pretend that there aren't people on Steam who will try to act tough and say that beating a game that generates everything completely at random is based on some sort of "skill" or "good judgment". There's the power of decision making, and then there's just plain ol' being outmatched by a robot that leveled up several times more than your randomly-generated loot chest equipment can possibly hope to combat.No, there's good decision making, and then there's numbers. Tactical games have always been about numbers. They have always been about well-crafted maps with careful enemy placement as much as they have been about intelligent team setup supported by guaranteed available items in shops (because the game knows you will need them). Bionic Dues does none of this. Bionic Dues generates all of the maps and the enemies that are placed into them with a computer algorithm. It generates which combinations of enemies will be in a map with a computer algorithm. It generates what level those enemies will be with a computer algorithm. Need to outfit your team in order to survive? Too bad. Bionic Dues also generates the items available in the shop with a computer algorithm. Basically, EVERYTHING is generated almost entirely at random. And as much as I'd like to believe that the computer procedures used in the generation of everything in this game are as intelligent and discerning as a human being... they're not.If you like to sit at a table and roll dice over and over again until you get a certain number, this game might be for you. Yeah, sure, delude yourself into thinking that there is some kind of decision you can make that will mystically cause your severely under-equipped robot to beat a hulking level 7 DoomBot - it seems to be what "roguelike" fans tend to do so they can convince themselves that everything they accomplished in a playthrough was totally the product of their skill. Is this game possible? Sure. I'm just so not afraid to say it straight: this game is absurdly random. It is a total crapshoot what items I will get, meaning it's a total crapshoot how powerful I will be, and it's a total crapshoot how the enemies will level up, meaning it's a total crapshoot whether or not I will beat them. The game is a total crapshoot. But like I said, some people like sitting at a table rolling dice over and over again until they get a certain number. Some people like crap(s).P.S. Please, really don't try to say that this review is because I can't handle the game. I've beaten the game 3 times on Expert and destroyed 100 enemies in a single shot. That is so not the issue. Only somebody extremely near-sighted bases their opinions on whether or not they can beat a game. This game is not good. It is an awful representation of tactical games. The tactical game genre should be ashamed of this game, it's giving the genre a bad name.

												Hmm... where to begin.First up, this is an Arcen Games title. The guys who took a dump on KB/M users with AVWW 2, and insulted them after they finally gave in and provided "real" mouse support for it.Now that that PSA is out of the way:The game is a little bit like AI War in a single city. Interesting for a while, but it gets repetitive and grindy in all the wrong ways. You'll spend far more time hunting for the "right" upgrades and managing your inventory than engaging in missions. Short ranged units are at a horrendous disadvantage, given that many rooms are loaded to the brim with enemies with medium to high range weaponry, and the investment needed to make their weapons viable is extreme. A Sniper unit will outperform an Assassin unit 100% of the time. And the game likes to set an Assassin in the default party loadout, and the fact that it also sets two heavy AOE units in the default loadout should be a key warning sign.Of course, the RNG Gods play a key role in this game, and like the RNG Gods everywhere, they are fickle, arbitrary and hate you.The lack of real campaign customization is another drawback, but that is a common issue for Arcen games. Sometimes, it's good to have a real short burst game, and other times, a longer campaign would be more interesting. Sometimes you want to give yourself a moderate challenge in ways that the few selectable "challenges" do not provide. Let's move on to other parts:The audio tracks are taken from AVWW 1. This does not surprise me for some reason, although I must say I'm disappointed, especially since the audio doesn't add to the experience.Graphics: It's a tiled game. No surprises, no real expectations, although background (or environmental) images would be nice.All around, I'm just not able to recommend this game. It's just missing far too many little things, and Arcen has done better in the past.

												I read about the insane difficulty level, and the hard-to-see icons on the battlefield, and the lack of a tutorial, and the lack of informative tooltips, but I thought, "That is all just QQ. Seriously, it can't be that bad. Besides, I LIKE roguelites! I will be okay, and if I can only get in 5 or 6 missions before I have to restart, that's okay. At least I will have had fun for 5 or 6 missions.No. Just no. First mission, I did okay on. I have yet to beat a second mission. The battlefield is cluttered and hard to read, the enemies' power ramps up so fast that you will get whiplash just watching them, and the junk you pick up, A.)is not worth equipping, and B.)even the store won't pay you for it so that you can get better junk.The tooltips are not nearly deep enough. For example, my assault mech is decent at anything shield-related. Cool! That means it is high health, has regen, and I forget what the third shield-related stat is. Problem: The assault mech DOES NOT HAVE REGEN. What's more, its health is so low that it can barely make it through a single mission, and it is the best mech for shooting wars! (Oh, and everything is a shooting war, so good luck.)I have heard much about the "strategy" in this game: don't believe it. Strategy consists of hiding around the corner and trying to snipe the enemy mechs before they one-shot you.As an example of the difficulty level in the game, I just quit a campaign in which I faced ninjas that reduced my line of sight, batbots which can one-shot me if they get close enough (which is still further than the range of my primary weapon, and tigerbots that have 2000 HEALTH! (My weapons do ~300 damage.) Believe it or not, I can actually handle everything I just mentioned, but then I run out of ammunition, and can do nothing but lay down and die.Don't bother with this game. The difficulty ramps up way too fast, the screen is cluttered, and you will have a hard time beating the second mission. Out of 50 missions.

												This game contains the hardest dilemma you'll ever face on a videogame: Which character will I pick?-The black girl with a tiny head-The blonde with a tumor on her face-The fugly nerdy girl-The scarred guy with a giraffe neck-The gaysian-The black guy with lipstickI don't know much about the gameplay, tried a couple of levels on "normal" mode, and got myself wrecked (mostly by Insta-kill bots, Allahu-Akhbots, halls filled with mines with no other way to go around them, and the list goes on). Maybe I lost some important info in one of the text walls that the game calls 'tutorials'.But what really annoys me is the art. I guess this was the best they could afford - a guy that has some crappy aesthetic sense, and can't make proportional human-like figures.By the way, I picked the black guy with lipstick.*Edit: ------FUN PART OF REVIEW ENDS HERE------ Wall of text below.Due to extensive criticism, I decided to be a bit more detailed on aspects regarding gameplay.1. Some screenshots can be pretty misleading. To clarify this, in this game you control a single unit, that alternates between what some people may call "stances". However, the game likes to say that these stances are actually, individual mechs. Moving on - there's the assault stance mech (the one that shoots), the siege mech (the one that deals area damage), the ninja mech (the one that hides), and the science mech (the one that opens doors and hacks stuff). Note, however, that the assault can still do some AoE like the siege, and hide like the ninja, but not quite as effective.2. The game is heavily based on RNG. Traps, enemies and drops are generated and spawned by a computer algorithm, meaning that your outcome on a mission can be pretty much decided by a roll of dice. You may find a bunch of chests, filled with nice loot the same way you can find a narrow hallway filled with mines. That leaves no space for skill-based (or, in this case, smarts-based?) gameplay, just frustration and unfair situations.3. As I already said, presentation is horrible (and yes, I'm still regarding gameplay here). Not just the art is badly drawn, but the menus are also dreadful. At some point, you'll have to deal with your inventory, that will be filled with items that you got during your missions (woah, a bunch of loot! cool! ... right?). Trying to sort your stash, and figure out which item will fit best to which mech rapidly becomes a tedious task, the more items you get.So... yeah, that's all, folks.

												Bionic ♥♥♥♥ing Dues!To me, this feels like what "Sword of the Stars : The Pit" should've played like. At times, the gameplay will feel a bit off since you're gonna be reacting to the enemies' movement and provoking them, rather than just diving in and killing everything like in most games. Still, that's just a tiny part of the actual playtime, and the music is simply amazing, so it fills up the little downtimes you may have. Talking about the music, it's so amazing that whenever I stop playing, I always feel like the current track is slightly out of context (especially menu song)... Yet, all of them are so melodious and non-intrusive that it only ends up as a positive experience overall (I've had the menu song loop for ~30 minutes right now...)So, let's see if you should buy this game or not... What this game offers : - Squad management : You control 1 character, but can swap between 4 exos. The first thing you do when you create a game is choose your "avatar" (aka 1 special game-changing skill), and 4 exos which have their own specialties. - Equipment management : Each mecha has a reactor, shield, propulsor, computer and 2-5 weapons. Each of those have 2-4(5?) slots for items. You have to mix multiple stats while managing power usage to create your indestructible monsters. - Tactical fight : Lay down mines and turrets, go stealthed to "charm" their leader and run away sneakily, Use your shotgun to explode the fuel tank and make everything i nthat room ashes... This game offers it all. I haven't tried the 2 hardest difficulties yet, but the tactical side may even make the game slightly too easy. - Amazing music : I said it already, saying it again, the OST is  at the very least charming. 												Bionic Dues is another game by Arcen Games, and it features many similar elements as their most popular series- AI War Fleet Command- AI Rebellion, weakened humanity, difficult/punishing gameplay, sharp difficulty curve, slow paced thoughtful gameplay, occasional oversights in the tutorials due to game mechanics.However, where AI War was a strategy game involving often absurd numbers of ships, in extreme cases numbering in the tens of thousands, Bionic Dues is a much smaller game. The city map is randomly generated, as are the actual maps from what I can tell. The abilities and variation between the various "Exos" the player can pilot are both interesting and well definied, with each having a 'niche' that is generally obvious (brawling, assault, sniper, hacking, etc), but with smaller 'modules' that allow you to customize each "Exo" to fit your own playstyle. The difficulty ramps up rather well, but I've found on lower difficulties its easy to become slightly overpowered. Individual variation between mission types helps keep the game from getting repetitive, as do various "Pilots" you can select from the beginning that give you a bonus that will significantly effect the nature of your play. (One gets bonuses for the shopkeepers, one starts out with epic units, one has the ability to pursue missions futher away, etc.)The game is not without flaws. It has the Mass Effect problem where every mission gives you loot for surviving units, and most missions have hackable doors and lootable cans, making keeping track of modules, especially late game, a bit of a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ It also occasionally becomes too open, with a lack of really clearly defined goals besides "upgrade your equipment and survive the invasion in 40 days".The soundtrack is mostly rehashed from AI War, with a few new introductions. It fits the game well, but players looking for a new album by Pablo Vega may be disappointed. I feel a need to point out that the turn based element is one I particularly like. Preforming any action costs a turn (moving, shooting most weapons, hacking, etc.), and then the robots will each move. However, Bionic Dues has no request prompts, so if you simply want to run across the map you can do so in realtime, but you can simply step away from the keyboard at any point if you wish and the game will wait for you. It allows you to pick your own pacing- Will you run in blasting anything that moves as the robots charge you down? Maybe you'll sit back and analyze each robot and pick the most efficient attack pattern, or maybe throw down an ambush using automated defenses, mines, or an enemy you hacked into being on your side.If you don't like replaying games trying to work different mechanics, Bionic Dues may not be for you. Those looking for a well developed story will find very little of that here (lots of setting, but the plot is something you make yourself).In any case, I happily recommend Bionic Dues.

If you're looking for a little bit of turn-based strategy in your Rogue-like RPG, Bionic Dues will fill that need. Just keep in mind that the game can be very convoluted in the way it presents your goals: your ultimate goal is to upgrade and survive for a pre-determined number of turns before the machines make their final assault on your base. The asking price of $10 is more than fair for a game with this level of replayability, so long as you're willing to put in the time to learn the nuance of the rules at play. Even if you aren't, consider buying Bionic Dues on sale if you enjoy more traditional Rogue-like titles.

												A competent turn-based tactical game from Arcen Games.  In Bionic Dues you control a squad of four 'exos' (remotely piloted mechs) one at a time to stop the advancing robot menace.  The game features random loot, as popularized by Diablo, an overall strategy screen, and the tactical map where all the robot stomping happens.  You have 50 days (turns) to prosecute a campaign against the tide of robots trying to eradicate humanity.  Each day you choose an available mission for your exos from those shown on teh city map.  After 50 days the remaining mass of robots arrive on your doorstep, and you have to KILL THEM ALL!For the most part the robots themselves, and the AI controlling them, are pretty dumb.  The 'bots try to crush your puny human resistance through sheer numbers, rather than any sort of awesome tactical genius.  On a similar note, though, there isn't much randomness to the combat itself.  You never feel cheated because your stupid exo managed to miss several shots in a row, or because you didn't realize that 'bot could shoot you.  All the info you need to make good decisions is right there on the screen.Audio and music are competent.  Everything sounds pew-pew and rata-tata as you'd expect.  The music isn't the sort of thing I'd listen to in the car, but I enjoy it enough to listen to it as I play.Graphics are clear enough that you can understand what's going on, but not spectacular.  It's 2D, top-down, tactical game, so a step up from pixel graphics, but you can't really admire the robot models, because there aren't any.The game isn't quite the same tactical depth of FTL, but your exos have a lot of options available to them.  Equipping them with loot is almost its own mini-game, and you will see a LOT of loot over the course of the game.  The biggest complaint I had of my first game was that the 'bots were a pushover.  I felt like I was moshing 'bots with impunity after only 20 turns or so, and by turn 40 I just wanted it to be over because I was so thoroughly dominating them.  That first game took 17 hrs to finish.  There are a decent amount of options for replayability, with six different commanders and exo types (each game you have a single commander, and up to four different exos).I enjoy turn-based tactics games like this, so it was worth the ten bucks I spent.  Definitely worth it if you can get it on sale.

												Bionic Dues is another game by Arcen Games, and it features many similar elements as their most popular series- AI War Fleet Command- AI Rebellion, weakened humanity, difficult/punishing gameplay, sharp difficulty curve, slow paced thoughtful gameplay, occasional oversights in the tutorials due to game mechanics.However, where AI War was a strategy game involving often absurd numbers of ships, in extreme cases numbering in the tens of thousands, Bionic Dues is a much smaller game. The city map is randomly generated, as are the actual maps from what I can tell. The abilities and variation between the various "Exos" the player can pilot are both interesting and well definied, with each having a 'niche' that is generally obvious (brawling, assault, sniper, hacking, etc), but with smaller 'modules' that allow you to customize each "Exo" to fit your own playstyle. The difficulty ramps up rather well, but I've found on lower difficulties its easy to become slightly overpowered. Individual variation between mission types helps keep the game from getting repetitive, as do various "Pilots" you can select from the beginning that give you a bonus that will significantly effect the nature of your play. (One gets bonuses for the shopkeepers, one starts out with epic units, one has the ability to pursue missions futher away, etc.)The game is not without flaws. It has the Mass Effect problem where every mission gives you loot for surviving units, and most missions have hackable doors and lootable cans, making keeping track of modules, especially late game, a bit of a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ It also occasionally becomes too open, with a lack of really clearly defined goals besides "upgrade your equipment and survive the invasion in 40 days".The soundtrack is mostly rehashed from AI War, with a few new introductions. It fits the game well, but players looking for a new album by Pablo Vega may be disappointed. I feel a need to point out that the turn based element is one I particularly like. Preforming any action costs a turn (moving, shooting most weapons, hacking, etc.), and then the robots will each move. However, Bionic Dues has no request prompts, so if you simply want to run across the map you can do so in realtime, but you can simply step away from the keyboard at any point if you wish and the game will wait for you. It allows you to pick your own pacing- Will you run in blasting anything that moves as the robots charge you down? Maybe you'll sit back and analyze each robot and pick the most efficient attack pattern, or maybe throw down an ambush using automated defenses, mines, or an enemy you hacked into being on your side.If you don't like replaying games trying to work different mechanics, Bionic Dues may not be for you. Those looking for a well developed story will find very little of that here (lots of setting, but the plot is something you make yourself).In any case, I happily recommend Bionic Dues.
